content: Neutron stars are so dense that a teaspoon of them would weigh about 6 billion tons.
The footprints left by astronauts on the Moon will likely stay there for millions of years due to lack of wind.
One million Earths could fit inside the Sun.
There is a giant cloud of alcohol in Sagittarius B2 which contains enough ethyl alcohol to fill 400 trillion pints of beer.
Olympus Mons on Mars is the tallest volcano in the solar system, standing three times the height of Mount Everest.
A day on Venus (243 Earth days) is longer than a year on Venus (225 Earth days).
The Milky Way galaxy is on a collision course with the Andromeda galaxy; they will merge in about 4.5 billion years.
If two pieces of the same type of metal touch in space, they will bond and be permanently stuck together. This is called cold welding.
The Sun accounts for 99.86% of the mass in the solar system.
There are more stars in the universe than grains of sand on all the beaches on Earth.
Jupiter has 95 recognized moons, making it the planet with the most moons in our solar system.
Black holes are not empty spaces; they are a great amount of matter packed into a very small area.
Light from the Sun takes about 8 minutes and 20 seconds to reach Earth.
The Great Red Spot on Jupiter is a storm that has been raging for at least 400 years and is larger than Earth.
Voyager 1 is the most distant human-made object from Earth.
Exoplanet 55 Cancri e is believed to be covered in graphite and diamonds.
The hottest planet in our solar system is Venus, not Mercury, due to its thick atmosphere trapping heat.
Saturn's rings are made primarily of ice particles, with some rocky debris and dust.
A light-year is the distance light travels in one year, which is about 6 trillion miles (9.5 trillion km).
The observable universe is estimated to be about 93 billion light-years in diameter.
Uranus spins on its side, rolling around the Sun like a ball.
The first person to look at space through a telescope was Galileo Galilei in 1609.
Neutrinos are ghost-like particles that pass through Earth (and you) by the trillions every second without touching anything.
The sound of the Big Bang was not a bang, but more of a deep hum, though sound cannot travel in the vacuum of space as we know it.
There is a hexagonal-shaped storm at Saturn's north pole.
Humans are made of stardust; the elements in our bodies were forged in the cores of dying stars.
Pluto was reclassified from a planet to a dwarf planet in 2006.
The International Space Station orbits Earth about every 90 minutes.
Magnetars are neutron stars with magnetic fields a trillion times stronger than Earth's.
Space is completely silent because there is no atmosphere to carry sound waves.
